results.title: The Louvre (PC)
results.brief_description: Take an armchair trip through le Grand Louvre in Paris and discover why it is one of the world’s great museums. There is the option of taking guided tours of the masterpieces and being provided with narration, a history of the building and playing the cour caree game where you can reassemble paintings to your own specifications. SYSTEM REQUIREMENTS: 486 DX or higher (Pentium recommended), Windows 3.1 or higher, 8 MB of RAM, 4Mb hard drive space, 2x speed CD-ROM drive (4x recommended), 640x480 screen, 256 colors (32,000 recommended).

results.title: The Lost world of the Maya
results.creator_credit: David Collison and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: For over a thousand years the Maya civilisation grew and flourished in the rain forests of Central America until it was discovered and destroyed by the Spanish conquistadores. Eric Thompson, well-known authority on the Maya, describes the struggle to comprehend the vanished civilisation, and the fight to preserve its treasures for posterity. Sites featured are Tikal, Palenque, Yaxchilan, Copan, Quirigua, Chichen Itza, Uxmal and Tulum.

results.title: The Lost pharaoh: the search for Akhenaten
results.creator_credit: Nicholas Kendall, Tom Daly and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: The fascinating story of an ancient Pharaoh and the archaeological sleuthing which went into piecing together information about his life. An accidental discovery in 1975 by Canadian archaeologist Dr. Donald Redford and his team led to the uncovering of the foundation of one of Akhenaten’s temples. Commentary and narration by Donald Brittain.

results.title: The Lost James Brown tapes
results.creator_credit: Alan Douglas, Chris Mould and Gravity
results.brief_description: Exciting live concert footage of the master of funk and godfather of soul, the inimitable James Brown. Supposedly shot in Monterey, California in 1979, this live concert shows the master in fine form. His powerful voice and trademark dance moves don’t disappoint but the transition to DVD format is a little dubious (may have been shot off a television screen). The ten songs featured are: “Get up offa that thing”, “Body heat”, “Try me”, “Sex machine”, “Georgia on my mind”, “Please please please”, “Hindsight”, “Can’t stand it”, “Papa’s got a brand new bag” and “Jam”. Original producers of the live concert footage were Eric Therman, Rod Crowe and Robert Sheridan. The title listed on the cover (as opposed to the actual work) is “James Brown: Body Heat Live”.

results.title: The Lord of the rings: the fellowship of the rings (Special extended edition) [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Peter Jackson, Fran Walsh, Tim Sanders, New Line Cinema and Wingnut Films
results.brief_description: Iconic adaptation of J R R Tolkien’s fantasy epic, “The Lord of the rings: the fellowship of the rings” is the first instalment of the “Rings” trilogy. Director Peter Jackson (Heavenly creatures, The Frighteners, Meet the Feebles) went to incredible lengths to re-create Tolkien’s fantastical vision to the screen by building extensive sets in his native New Zealand and by employing a slew of gifted special effects artists. In short, Frodo Baggins, a kind-hearted and earnest hobbit, is entrusted with the gallant mission to return a powerful ring from whence it came - Mount Doom, the only place where it can be destroyed. Failure to do so will result in the destruction of the earth, as the powerful ring is capable of unleashing inestimable evil. Guided by Gandalf, a powerful wizard, Frodo is accompanied on his treacherous journey by three hobbit friends, a dwarf, an elf and several humans. This heroic quest invokes all the necessary thrills of an adventure picture, whilst satiating the exacting standards of an audience inured to CGI wizardry, and gratifying legions of zealous Tolkien fans. With ambitious battle scenes and stupendous set pieces, this grand and masterful cinematic spectacle kept most viewers utterly enthralled, whilst earning Jackson almost universal praise for capturing Tolkien’s mythopoeic narrative and elegiac tone.

results.title: The Lorax (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Hawley Pratt, Isadore Freleng and DePatie-Freleng Enterprises
results.brief_description: Presents the story from the book “The Lorax” by Dr. Seuss. A fanciful tale with a serious theme: clean up the environment before it’s too late. In this delightful story the student is introduced to the needs of everyman. And the Lorax? Who is he and what does he do? Only Dr. Seuss can describe the creature - which he does with typical Seussian logic.

results.title: The Loon's necklace
results.brief_description: A re-creation of a legend of the Indians of British Colombia, using carved ceremonial masks of the Indians and animated drawings. The loon is a North American water bird. The story tells of Kelora, a blind medicine man. During a hard winter, his village suffers from famine, and is attacked by hungry wolves. Using his magic bow, Kelora is able to kill the wolves. In Spring, Kelora seeks out the loon, his “father”, and the loon gives him the power to see. In gratitude Kelora takes his most precious possession, a bead necklace, and throws it round the loon’s neck. That is how the loon came to get his collar of bright feathers.

results.title: The Longhouse people
results.creator_credit: Allan Wargon, Tom Daly and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: The life and religious ceremonies of the Longhouse people - Iriquois Indians who adhere to the old religion. We see how the Iroquois of today, although fully adapted to the ways of the white people, still maintain a link with their proud past through observance of the customs and beliefs of their forefathers. Highlights of the film show an outdoor dance in supplication for rain, a healing ceremony performed by men of the False-Face Society and a dance in celebration of a newly chosen chief.

results.title: The Long way back
results.creator_credit: Donald Ginsberg, Guy Glover and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: This film shows how the mental health volunteer fits into the treatment of mental illness. It shows that patients in a mental hospital respond more quickly to treatment if kept in touch with the outside world. A film of importance to mature men and women who may wish to offer their services as volunteers. (Award: Columbus)
